title: How to Pronounce the Letters of the French Alphabet

steps.title: Listen to the alphabet pronounced by a native speaker.
steps.content: Listen to the alphabet pronounced by a native speaker. You can use YouTube to find many examples of people saying the alphabet, and hearing it is often better than trying to read it. Search online to hear each letter as it is pronounced. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce A like "Ah."
steps.content: Pronounce A like "Ah." Open your mouth wide to pronounce the first letter. This is similar to a "soft A" in English. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce B like "Bey" or "Bay."
steps.content: Pronounce B like "Bey" or "Bay." This is a soft sound, like saying "Hey" in English. Think of the first syllable in the word "baby." [4] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce C like "seh."
steps.content: Pronounce C like "seh." The is the first letter that varies strongly from the English equivalent. You can also soften the "ay" sound to be more like an "e," pronouncing it "Cey," like the first sound in the word "saving." [5] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce D like "deh."
steps.content: Pronounce D like "deh." Similar to B, C and, later on, V and T. All of these letters use the soft "eh" sound preceded by the letter in question.

steps.title: Pronounce F like "ef," exactly how it is pronounced in English.
steps.content: Pronounce F like "ef," exactly how it is pronounced in English. The same sound is used in French as English. L, M, N, O, and S are also pronounced like their English counterparts. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce H like "ahsh."
steps.content: Pronounce H like "ahsh." The beginning is a soft A sound, like "ahhhh," followed by the "sh." It is similar to the sound of the slang word "gosh." [7] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce I like "ee," using a long E sound in English.
steps.content: Pronounce I like "ee," using a long E sound in English. I is pronounced like the E in "see" or "be."

steps.title: Pronounce K like "kah."
steps.content: Pronounce K like "kah." This is another easy one. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce L, M, N, and O like their American counterparts.
steps.content: Pronounce L, M, N, and O like their American counterparts. These are simple and easy. They sound just like the English version &rarr: "el," "em," "en," and "oh." [9] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce P like "peh."
steps.content: Pronounce P like "peh." It is as simple as the English word for making some money.

steps.title: Pronounce R like "err," but with a slightly rolled R.
steps.content: Pronounce R like "err," but with a slightly rolled R. If you can't roll your Rs, that is okay. A simple "err" will suffice. It is similar to the first syllable of the English word "error." [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce S like "es," similar to English.
steps.content: Pronounce S like "es," similar to English. The S is the same sound in both languages. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce T like "teh."
steps.content: Pronounce T like "teh." A simple pronunciation, similar to B and D. Rhymes with "say." [12] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce V like "veh."
steps.content: Pronounce V like "veh." Again, this is a simple pronunciation. Rhymes with "day." [13] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce W like "doob-leh-veh."
steps.content: Pronounce W like "doob-leh-veh." This translates literally to "double V." Just like in English, W is essentially pronounced like 2 separate words -- "Doob-leh" and "veh." [14] X Research source The word "double," in French, sounds a bit like "dooblay."

steps.title: Pronounce X like "eecks."
steps.content: Pronounce X like "eecks." Another way to think about it is "eex." X is not a very common French letter, and sounds more an English X, just with a long E sound before the letter. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce Z like "zed."
steps.content: Pronounce Z like "zed." Simple and easy, this is actually how many British people pronounce Z in English. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce E like "euh.'
steps.content: Pronounce E like "euh.' This is a very guttural sound, almost like you think something is gross or disgusting. Think of the vowel sign in the word "took," as in, "she took my example." [17] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce G like "jeh," with a soft G sound.
steps.content: Pronounce G like "jeh," with a soft G sound. Think of it as saying "jeh," but elongating the j slightly so that is sounds more like an "sh" sound. Think of the G sounds in "George." [18] X Research source The pronunciation rhymes with the English name "Shea."

steps.title: Pronounce J like "jhee."
steps.content: Pronounce J like "jhee." This is just like the pronunciation of G, but with an E sound instead of an A. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce U like "e-yooh," and know that this is probably the hardest letter to pronounce.
steps.content: Pronounce U like "e-yooh," and know that this is probably the hardest letter to pronounce. A good trick for saying U is to start saying a hard E sound, like "eeee," then move move your lips forward as if you were saying "You." This somewhat "compound" sound is tricky, and easiest to learn by listening to native speakers. It is very similar to an exaggerated sound of disgust in English, "ewwwww," but it starts with a very pronounced E sound. [20] X Research source Your tongue and mouth are situated like an "eee" sound. Your lips are rounded in an "O" shape.

steps.title: Pronounce Q like "kyoo" or "cue."
steps.content: Pronounce Q like "kyoo" or "cue." It is similar to the English version, but you slightly de-emphasize the y sound in the middle. It is similar to the French pronunciation of U. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Pronounce Y like "ee-greck."
steps.content: Pronounce Y like "ee-greck." The oddest pronunciation in the alphabet, Y has two sounds: "ee-greck." The second part sounds a bit like "gekko" with an R and no O. [22] X Research source You do not, however, want to pause between "ee" and "greck." Think of it as a two syllable word.

steps.title: Know how to talk about the various accents.
steps.content: Know how to talk about the various accents. When adding accents to letters, such as when spelling something for someone, you usually add the inflection or mark after the letters. So, for "è" you would say "e, accent à grave," (or, phonetically, "eh, ak-cent ah grav"). The accents are pronounced: A right pointing dash (`) is an "accent à grave." Pronounce "ah-grav." A left-pointing dash (such as in é), is an "accent aigu." Pronounce "ah-goo." A point up (^) is known as a "circumflex." It is pronounced just like it looks.

steps.title: Learn to pronounce the special characters.
steps.content: Learn to pronounce the special characters. French has a few extra letters and combinations, which brings the total to 34 letters. The additional ones are: Ç ( Ss ) (Also known as a çedilla, or "sirdiya") Œ ( Oo ) Æ ( Ay ) â ( Ah ) ê ( Eh ) î ( Ih ) ô ( Oah ) û ( Oh ). [23] X Research source

steps.title: Review the pronunciation of the entire alphabet.
steps.content: Review the pronunciation of the entire alphabet. Once you have them all down. try saying them in order to practice your pronunciation: A (ahh), B (bay), C (say), D (day), E (euh), F (f),G (jhay), H (ahsh), I (ee), J (jhee), K (kaa), L (l), M (m), N (n), O (o), P (pay), Q (kyoo), R (err(rolled r)), S (es), T (tay), U (e-yooh), V (vay), W (dooblay-vey), X (ix), Y (ee-greck), Z (zed). [24] X Research source [25] X Research source
